content.description: This may have been my first, FA. It is a thin hand crack. The crux is at the top, where the crack thins out and requires a lung for a ledge.
content.protection: hand size
content.location: mid canyon, right side as you walk back.

content.description: Almost all the way back the canyon on the north east wall. Their is another similar looking line up canyon but not as clean directly across canyon from the route Last Rights. It would be easy to get the two confused. (The old MP photo was of this route) The easiest way to locate this line for me is if you walk up canyon as going to the namaste wall on your right is a arching crack with a brand new single bolt at the bottom. It is directly across canyon from this. Some binoculars will help any adventure in Kolob.
content.protection: hooks, beaks and #2 cams
content.location: 2/3 of the way back the canyon

content.description: The crux is definitely passing the bolts and traversing to the crack. Beautiful jamming and liebacks follow until it is possible to face climb on solution pockets, protecting in the crack. Toward the top, hollowed out solution pockets may be tied off with runners to protect the final moves. Rappel the route.
content.protection: 2 blots to protect the start after that cams 2ea. #2, 2.5, 3, 3.5, 4 Friends or similar. Lots of runners.
content.location: The route is about 50 yds to the left of tail of the cock.  It will be obvious with the 2 bolt start from the picture.

content.description:
Tango begins just left of Tail of the Cock on Rooster Pinnacle.

Pitch 1 - Start out with 5.10a moves protected by small stoppers.  Lieback and jamming follows for 30 feet to a very comfortable belay ledge.

Pitch 2 - Continue up 10 feet, traverse left across a platform until you can step further left across to the main crack.  Small wired's and tcu's protect thin face moves up to clip a bolt, then left onto a small ledge.  Traverse up and right from here reaching for an angled ledge and huecos above.  Continue jamming and liebacks to a platform. Step left clipping a second bolt and continue up and left to anchors.
content.protection: 2 bolts, # 0, 1,2,3 tcu's, cams to 3.5, small to medium stoppers and lots of runners.
content.location: Tango begins just left of Tail of the Cock on Rooster Pinnacle. It trends left to end at the top of Pillar of Salt.  Consult "B" in the photo for more details.

climbs.name: Tail Of The Cock
climbs.fa: Bob Draney and Sebastian Luque circa 1994

content.description:
Follow the corner crack all the way to the top of the formation.  It gets loose at the top and the crux is in the middle of the climb. From the top you can rappel down or try out new sport climbs that someone put up traversing onto some huecos.

--- Invalid image id: 107892601 ---
content.protection: Standard Trad Rack. Anchors ar the top.
content.location:
The Route is on the Rooster Pinnacle and can be seen from the road.  The route is on the left side of the pinnacle.  Two ropes will get you to the ground with a 140' rappel.  You could break this climb up into two pitches.

--- Invalid image id: 107892597 ---

climbs.name: Special Sauce
climbs.fa: Todd Stephens (RIP), Troy Anderson, Trisha Breinholdt late ‘90s

content.description:
Rad sampler of local climbing.  4 pitches of slab, aid, cracks, towers, and sexy ledges make this a kick ass adventure. Register on top may need paper and a pen from this decade.

The route has been completely freed out to the left of the aid section.

This route is older than mountain project. Find trip reports and more info by searching for “Special Sauce” on

rockclimbing.com
content.protection:
Free climbing Zion trad rack to 4” +

Aid gear for the A0

(hooks, cam hooks, sky hooks, leeper hooks, RURPS, Tricams, toucans, stackers, peckers, sawed offs, leeper Zs, bongs, bashies, Black totems, c4s, x4s, C3s, dragons, screamers, peckers, standard nuts,

curved nuts, mi

cro offset brass nuts, micro offset aluminum nuts,  peanuts,  wallnuts, Ultralight Offset Supercams, keylatch rivet hangers, oval biners, D biners, ultralight micro wiregate biners, dyneema extendable alpine draws, french quickdraws with integrated frenchfree grab handles, body positioning Fifi hook, automatic extendable daisy chains, 4 step etriers with full strength grab loop, 6 step ladder style etriers with integrated handle and spreader bar, fingerless pigskin climbing gloves with integrated clip in loop, jumars, pullies, and maybe (or maybe not) a segmented double gear sling with storage compartment and removable bladder. . . . . Or maybe just some basic steps, daisies, jumars and extra ‘biners or draws. YMMV : )
content.location: 200 yards left of Rooster Pinnacle locate a towerish feature with a flat top aka “Suzie’s”. Walk to the bottom (7-10 minutes) and find the bottom of the route on a slab.

content.description: Crux is after the first bolt then makes way to easier climbing at the top.
content.protection: standard rack to 3"
content.location:
This route is on the right side of the rooster pinnacle.  140' to the ground.  Two Ropes.

--- Invalid image id: 107892601 ---

--- Invalid image id: 107892597 ---

content.description: This is a beautiful zig-zagging splitter finger crack on a black varnished wall. With the crux about 2/3 the way up.
content.protection: Small cams and nuts. 3 bolt anchor/rap station at the top of the climb.
content.location: Park at the obvious parking area on the right, cross the road. Walk up the trail to the second gully, witch drops south from the obvious towering buttress to the north. Follow a sandy trail up the gully to a slop on the right of a cave like amphitheater. Continue north to a small buttress behind some ponderosa pines. The route goes up the obvious crack.

content.description: Scramble up easy 4th class and belay from atop this ledge.  Ascend the crack, placing 1-3 inch cams in sketchy sandstone.  Beware, the roof overhead is unstable bombs, waiting to drop.  Move right around this, into a solid crack and rest on a huge ledge.  Keep moving up, placing gear anytime solid rock permits.  The top move is the crux.  Move to the opening to the left and grovel on slopers until you can top out.
content.protection: Standard rack.  I belayed from above using slung rock and roots as anchors.
content.location:
Approach:  Leave the parking lot and walk down the road 200 feet.  Scratch and crawl your way up a land slide to reach the base of the rock.

To get down, walk off back to the parking lot.

content.description:
Across from the dramatic, overhanging, tiger-striped wall that contains "Namaste" is a beautiful grey slab.  This area currently contains 6 lines.  From left to right they are:

Unknown Project:  Only two bolts thus far.

Extremely Tough Slab:  5.11d with a 5.13 extension (rumored).

Pins and Needles:  5.11a.

Pulp Friction:  5.10c.

Sand Surfin':  5.10b - currently a cracked hanger at bolt #2 and potentially very dangerous.

Self Abuse:  5.9 and a variation of Sand Surfin' that begins at it's third bolt and dodges off straight left to another line of bolts.

All of the climbs are generally well-protected slabs of varying difficulty proportional to the steepness of the wall.  I recommend starting with Sand Surfin' (skip Self Abuse) and working your way left down the wall until you get shut down.
content.protection: 6 bolts to an anchor.

content.description:
Across from the dramatic, overhanging, tiger-striped wall that contains "Namaste" is a beautiful grey slab.  This area currently contains 6 lines.  From left to right they are:

Self Abuse:  5.9 and a variation of Sand Surfin' that begins at it's third bolt and dodges off straight left to another line of bolts.

All of the climbs are generally well-protected slabs of varying difficulty proportional to the steepness of the wall.  I recommend starting with Sand Surfin' (skip Self Abuse) and working your way left down the wall until you get shut down.
content.protection: 7 bolts to an anchor.

content.description: Yet another slab climb.  A brief blank section by the fourth bolt leads to a shallow hueco.  Angle slightly left after the last bolt to the chains.
content.protection: 8 bolts to a chain anchor.
content.location:
Across from the dramatic, overhanging, tiger-striped wall that contains "Namaste" is a beautiful grey slab (the Marmot Slab). This area currently contains 6 lines. From left to right they are:

Unknown Project: Only two bolts thus far.

Extremely Tough Slab: 5.11d with a 5.13 extension (rumored).

Pins and Needles: 5.11a. - tan bolt hangers.

Pulp Friction: 5.10c. - about 75 feet right of Pins and Needles and 5 feet left of a left-facing flake.

Sand Surfin': 5.10b - also left of a left-facing flake.  Currently a cracked hanger at bolt #2 and potentially very dangerous.

Self Abuse: 5.9 and a variation of Sand Surfin' that begins at it's third bolt and dodges off straight left to another line of bolts.

All of the climbs are generally well-protected slabs of varying difficulty proportional to the steepness of the wall. I recommend starting with Sand Surfin' (skip Self Abuse) and working your way left down the wall until you get shut down.

content.description:
Across from the dramatic, overhanging, tiger-striped wall that contains "Namaste" is a beautiful grey slab (the Marmot Slab). This area currently contains 6 lines. From left to right they are:

Unknown Project: Only two bolts thus far.

Extremely Tough Slab: 5.11d with a 5.13 extension (rumored).

Pins and Needles: 5.11a. - tan bolt hangers.

Pulp Friction: 5.10c. - about 75 feet right of Pins and Needles and 5 feet left of a left-facing flake.

Sand Surfin': 5.10b - also left of a left-facing flake. Currently a cracked hanger at bolt #2 and potentially very dangerous.

Self Abuse: 5.9 and a variation of Sand Surfin' that begins at it's third bolt and dodges off straight left to another line of bolts.

All of the climbs are generally well-protected slabs of varying difficulty proportional to the steepness of the wall. I recommend starting with Sand Surfin' (skip Self Abuse) and working your way left down the wall until you get shut down.
content.protection: 9 bolts to a two-bolt, vertically-oriented Fixe rap anchor.

content.description:
After passing above the old debris dam and flood plain and hiking up canyon just about 200' west of Namaste on the South wall. This route is just left (East)of a huge left facing arch.

A bouldery start to a left trending flake (2 bolts) gets one to an obvious arching crack. Traverse into the crack and it goes from fingers to hands in about 45 to the belay chains.

When I first climbed this on aid in 1987 I found an old 2" angle lying in the dirt in a pod at the current rap anchor. I would LOVE to know who did the FA and when. There are faint bathook scars below the crack if you look carefully.
content.protection: 2 draws and a small rack of cams from 1/2" to 2"

content.description: Hueco climb which I believe was put up by Matt Barley. Six bolts of overhangy sandstone to anchors.
content.protection: Sport climb. Six bolts to the anchor.
content.location: Hueco climb on lower buttress about 7 minutes from the parking lot.

content.description: Traverse to the left
content.protection: 9 bolts to 2 bolts chains
content.location:
2nd pitch at the top of the rooster pinnacle.  Rap from the chains down.  you've got the option of 4 different routes to get to the start of this one.

--- Invalid image id: 107892601 ---

content.description: looks pretty straight forward.  1 bolt to protect the start.
content.protection: standard rack, 1 bolt to protect the start
content.location: right to the left of Tail of the cock.  There are anchors at the top of the climb.  I can either rappel from there for use this route to gain access to the Hueccos 2nd pitch climb --- Invalid image id: 107892601 ---

content.description: Climb huecos to anchors
content.protection: 10 bolts to 2 bolt anchor
content.location: the route is above hueco direct start.  You can use hueco direct start or the start of tail of the cock to gain access to the start of this 2nd pitch sport route.  Rap the route.

content.description: From the trail head, hike up canyon to the fifth wash on your left (just before the big sandy steps at the base of the debris dam). Hike up the wash (north) to the base of the south face of Paria Point. The route ascends a slab behind a large ponderosa pine. There are two distinct cruxes one low and one high. There is also a variation that avoids the hard climbing and drops the rating to 5.10c: Instead of climbing the bolt line directly, scamper up a shallow corner to the right and follow a line of 3 drilled angles that traverse in above the crux.
content.protection: 8 draws should suffice

content.description:
A couple hundred feet past Last Rites on the right hand side of the main canyon of South fork. A difficult slab route with two distinct cruxes.

The first is a funky mantle to some delicate sidepulls and the second is a strenuous and delicate step up smear to a pinch. The rest of the pitch is fun and aesthetic.
content.protection: 9 bolts

content.description: Splitter 5.6 crack up 30 feet.
content.protection: A few cams or highball it.

climbs.name: Expecting
climbs.fa: Bob and Kaydi Draney, Sebastian Luque 1994

content.description: Four pitches of slab climbing, face and chimney to the top out.
content.protection: There's a pin and a bolt but it's mostly runout on the slab until you hit the chimney where it eats up some big cams and passive gear.

content.description: There is a bolt to help protect the start.  follow the crack to the top of the formation to some face moves.
content.protection: standard rack as well as a bd#4
content.location:
Right down the center of the Rooster Pinnacle.  You can see this formation from the road.  Two ropes will get you to the bottom. 140' rappel.

--- Invalid image id: 107892601 ---

--- Invalid image id: 107892597 ---

content.description: Follow the arete to the top
content.protection: 10 bolts, anchors at the top.  You could also clip the first bolt of Tail of the Cock to make it 11 bolts.
content.location:
Between The Tail of the Cock and center route on the rooster pinnacle. 140ft to the ground.

--- Invalid image id: 107892601 ---

content.description: This is the crack that is visible on the small formation behind (North of) the small seasonal pond (usually filled in with grass) just above the debris dam on the hike up south fork. The crack starts out nice and varnished but soon turns scary and decomposed. Walk off the top.
content.protection: Pro to 1.5"

content.description: The good? It's in an awesome place and has some fun, yet challenging, friction and slab moves. The bad? It has some challenging friction and slab moves.
content.protection: A few bolts to chains.
content.location: It's been ten years... can't really remember. Will update later.
